abstract: South Korea passes anticorruption law imposing up to three years in prison for public servants, journalists and teachers who take single cash donations or gifts worth more than million won, or about $900; giving and taking cash and other gifts have been part of culture, and suspected form of bribery.
lead_paragraph: The law calls for up to three years in prison for journalists and teachers, as well as public servants, who accept single cash donations or gifts valued at more than a million won, or about $900.

headline.main: South Korea Tightens Rules Against Gifts to Fight Graft
headline.print_headline: South Korea Tightens Rules Against Gifts to Fight Graft

snippet: The law calls for up to three years in prison for journalists and teachers, as well as public servants, who accept single cash donations or gifts valued at more than a million won, or about $900.
